conclusion: Trying to solve a problem about a charged particle moving through two different magnetic fields.
Boundary between two uniform magnetic fields B1 and B2; B1 = 2B2.
Particle with charge +q and mass m enters B1 perpendicularly at point O.
Need to find out after how much time it will pass through point O again moving downward.
Particle starts at O, goes up into B1, crosses to B2, and returns through O.
Charged particle in a magnetic field moves in a circular path; radius R = (mv)/(qB).
Time period T for one complete circle is T = (2Ï€m)/(qB).
Particle isn't making a complete circle due to two different fields.
Heart-shaped path illustrated in picture 3 might represent the trajectory.
Analyze motion in each region separately and connect at the boundary.
In B1, particle follows a circular path with radius R1 = (mv)/(qB1).
Given B1 = 2B2, R1 = (mv)/(2qB2).
In B2, new radius R2 = (2mv)/(qB1).
R2 = 2 * R1, meaning radius in B2 is twice the radius in B1.
Visualize path as circular arc in B1, larger circle in B2, returning through O.
Direction changes when crossing the boundary; consider continuity of path.
Magnetic force F = qv x B, perpendicular to v and B, causes circular motion.
In B1, force F1 = qvB1; in B2, F2 = qvB2 = (1/2)F1.
Force in B2 is half the force in B1; path adjusts to new force.
Path in each region is a segment of a circle with radius determined by local field.
